title: Dependable Classical-Quantum Computer Systems Engineering
authors:
Edoardo Giusto (1), Santiago Nu\~nez-Corrales (2 and 3), Phuong Cao
  (2), Alessandro Cilardo (1), Ravishankar K. Iyer (3), Weiwen Jiang (6), Paolo
  Rech (4), Flavio Vella (4), Bartolomeo Montrucchio (5), Samudra Dasgupta (7),
  Travis S. Humble (7) ((1) University of Naples Federico II, Italy, (2)
  National Center for Supercomputing Applications, Urbana, IL, US, (3)
  University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, US, (4) University of Trento, Italy,
  (5) Politecnico di Torino, Italy, (6) George Mason University, VA, US, (7)
  Oak Ridge National Laboratory, TN, US)
abstract:
Quantum Computing (QC) offers the potential to enhance traditional
High-Performance Computing (HPC) workloads by leveraging the unique properties
of quantum computers, leading to the emergence of a new paradigm: HPC-QC. While
this integration presents new opportunities, it also brings novel challenges,
particularly in ensuring the dependability of such hybrid systems. This paper
aims to identify integration challenges, anticipate failures, and foster a
diverse co-design for HPC-QC systems by bringing together QC, cloud computing,
HPC, and network security. The focus of this emerging inter-disciplinary effort
is to develop engineering principles that ensure the dependability of hybrid
systems, aiming for a more prescriptive co-design cycle. Our framework will
help to prevent design pitfalls and accelerate the maturation of the QC
technology ecosystem. Key aspects include building resilient HPC-QC systems,
analyzing the applicability of conventional techniques to the quantum domain,
and exploring the complexity of scaling in such hybrid systems. This
underscores the need for performance-reliability metrics specific to this new
computational paradigm.
